reviewText:
Fast-paced and shamelessly entertaining // Best for those seeking an FPS throwback to simpler times (with better visuals)
+ Massive visual improvement over the original game; textures, models, and lighting all have been thrown far into the future compared to the game's original release
+ Introduces an autosave function
+ Offers cooperative play
+ Maps are large and allow for generous movement when in combat
+ Enemies attack in droves; spikes the difficulty, certainly, but also keeps the adrenaline flowing
+ The action is practically non-stop; there aren't any innovative mechanics by today's standards, but the consistent need for maneuvering and gunplay makes for a great, and a classic, mob shooter
+ The monster designes are surprisingly creative, if often campy and odd; here, too, the visuals have been given an overhaul, and the enemies are much more detailed as a result
+ There are secrets aplenty, often hidden behind walls
+ Applaudable level design
+ Weaponry benefits from a moderate variation and a deep satisfaction in their use

- With precious little breaking up the fast pace, the gameplay gradually becomes a bit too uniform; can give way to a sense of tedium if played for long hours at a time
- Multiplayer appears dead; completely unpopulated, and no active servers at the time of this review

reviewText:
Short version: 87%For those who missed the awesomeness of the first Serious Sam games, the HD remake is the perfect spot to jump into this old-school FPS franchise of serious weaponry, hordes of aliens, corny humour, and most importantly: lots and lots of mindless but oh-so-fun action.

Long version:After the not so enthusiastic reception of Serious Sam 2, CroTeam decided that it would be better if they returned the franchise to its roots. The result was Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter, which also marked the debut of third Serious Engine. (Apparently they wanted to erase the memory of SS2 so much that they released the remake before Serious Sam 3: BFE was finished.)

The finished product is mostly just a facelift on the original game, where the goal is still the same: use shotguns, rockets, cannons, and everything else in the vast arsenal to kill your way through a seemingly never-ending flood of monsters in ancient Egypt, all in order to stop an alien warlord called Mental before he eradicates humanity in the far future. All while finding silly little secrets and listening to the corniest one-liners any action hero ever spoken.
There are a few minor tweaks here and there: some new level secrets, rebalanced difficulty (easiest settings don’t reduce enemy health that much), and a few modified enemy spawn compositions or locations. They are not too large to make new players feel they don’t get the original experience, but enough to give something even for the veterans.

The graphical update is surprisingly humble. CroTeam touched the levels with respect, only making sure they were up to 2009’s standards, without adding unnecessary effects or any flashy things. This may come off as bad news for those who are used to FPS games being all about grandiose visuals and on-rails gameplay, but great news for those who want to know what makes these games so good but don’t want to go old-school in the graphical department.

reviewText:
This review is a little lengthy, so if you want a quick summary of why I recommend Serious Sam HD The First Encounter skip to Results and read from there.

Croteam makes a smash and they do it without any logic, realism, or sense.

The Campaign:
Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is an epic game which takes place in Ancient Egypt. This first person shooter is based in the future where the world is about to be destroyed by the monster Mental. All hope is lost until we discover that the way to defeat these monsters can be traced from our past. Further research reveals that humanity has discovered an ancient race the Sirians who had also fought and lost to Mental's might. Humanity finds the ancient Sirian technology known as the Time-Lock which can allow one person to traverse time and space. Our protagonist Sam, who may be very serious, is a champion, a hero, and a legend for humanity. Fighting off every alien he encounters to the end Sam, a true warrior, is given the ultimate task. To use the Time-Lock to travel back in time and to defeat Mental while he is busy dealing with the Sirians.

The Gameplay:
Serious Sam is revitalized in HD with a stunning thirteen levels (plus an additional two secret levels) digitally remastered and designed to meet the demand of modern day consumers. The graphics are not going to be anything like your blockbuster games, but that’s because the original was produced in 2001 and this is just a remastering. But the game looks rather clean and plays incredibly well. This game not only has secret levels, but is filled with little secrets for the avid gamer. Mysteries abound and things to find Serious Sam leaves you without want.

Result:
I played Serious Sam: The First Encounter only a little bit when it was released in 2001. Then purchased it recently because it was on sale. Not being an avid fan of the series I can definitely say this game is a fun purchase even if you never really played the original. There are an abundance of crazy enemies, a wacky story (that makes you keep wondering where all the humans are), awesome weapons, fun boss fights, and lots of crazy items. This game not only challenges you in combat making you feel like a hero, but also puts you to the test by throwing puzzles all over the place. The game requires you to solve puzzles, complete challenges, and defeat enemies in order to progress. The levels are long, the campaign is long, the game is a blast, it’s a must buy. If you like puzzles, you like first person shooters, you want nostalgia, or you just like to be a hero then this is the game for you.

Pros:
+Incredibly fast paced combat
+Puzzles in every level
+Secret levels and many secrets within each level.
+Lots of fun an interesting enemies
+An abundance of bosses
+Crazy amount of fun weapons to shoot about
+Digitally remastered and in 1080p
+Fun and gripping story that mixes reality with fantasy

Cons:
-There is a limit to the amount fo auto-saves, you will lose older auto-saves in order for new ones to save, but don't worry you can just continually make saves yourself (I had over 200 by the end of the campaign).
-The sensitivity can randomly spark (meaning it just shoots up and your character can suddenly turn with only the slightest mouse movement facing you the wrong way).

reviewText:
Serious Sam First Encounter HD is the remade version of the classical game from 2001, an excellent game with a new skin to keep it ready for a more graphics-wise judgemental audience. Serious Sam First Encounter HD will be a good buy for both new players wondering what the deal is with this thing and why everyone likes it, and the older gamers who remember the originals. It is as true to the original as it can get, with a few improvements.

Storywise, it's nothing to write home over. It's a fairly standard story for a game that relies more on its gameplay than on captivating you with word words and more words. Aliens happened, they're after you, you're in acient Egypt and you have guns. Good luck!
There is more to it, if you take the time to read into the story there are just enough flavourful blurbs and explanations around that you can read to figure out where your enemies came from, and parts of the storyline, though it isn't something that will carry you through the game, it's more like an extra.
The true power of Serious Sam is in the gameplay, with excellent level design, guns that are satisfying to use, and a very high skill ceiling allowing you to feel like a god laying down devastation on hordes of enemies, moving fast enough to dodge almost all of their fire (Since all but a few enemies use projectiles, this means you can dodge nearly everything with enough practice) yet not too fast to become unmanagable. This, along with plentiful secrets, and a game that won't just say 'no' and throw up an invisible wall if you move slighly off the beaten path means that Serious Sam has an excellent grasp the concept of what great games are about- Freedom

Freedom to choose your own tactics (And most are valid as well! No need to gimp yourself)
Freedom to move as you please
Freedom to explore the levels and find all the secrets
And the freedom to handle any encounter in the way you want to.

Along with this, Egypt as pictured is a somewhat unique setting for an FPS game, with a lot of it lending itself for interesting levels and impressive scenery. The enemies you face are unique and mostly iconic as well, with the beheaded bomber and kleer skeleton being some of the more known enemies. In addition, Serious Sam has a great sense of humour, and you can play with a friend, two friends, or a whole army of friends.

If you're interested in a great FPS game, this is a game for you.

The high definition remake of the original Serious Sam: TFE turned out to breathe some serious new life into the game.  One of the original kings of the FPS genre, Serious Sam does a lot of things right, with a few things wrong, and suffers a tad from being a bit of an old title.

The boss fights are pretty fun and in general the game is still really fun, the added benefit of the HD remaster in graphical fidelity and a few new features (autosave, etc...) really gets Sam back in the game.

I would recommend this game to anyone who likes new or old FPS games, just give it a try, you might like it.

reviewText:
Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is a remake of Serious Sam: The First Encounter, as you could guess. It was released in 2009 by Croteam and was also known as the first game to use Serious Engine 3. And yep, as serious as ever.
It also came out on X360 through Xbox Live service. The only difference that I am aware of is that it had multiplayer only up to 4 players and aim assist.

Multiplayer community seems to be dead. Okay, maybe not completely, I did get into some match once at one day. But in other times server list is completely empty. And it makes sense, since Serious Sam HD: The Second Encounter has Fusion feature which means that owners of SSHD:TFE get to have Egypt levels to be ported into that game. So instead most of people play in SSHD:TSE.

Premise of original Serious Sam is that Sam Stone is sent into past into Egypt to try to stop the Mental forces before they destroy the Earth. And to do this he would need to pass many levels that have sections designed to serve as arenas to lock players inside. You didn't have as much exploration as in Doom or whatever Quake clone game. Instead it was more focused in pacing and tactical choices during combat itself, with encounters lasting few waves, as enemies keep pressuring you to move around. There were a lot of different enemy types and you had a lot of different specialized weapons, so you would have to choose correct gun for each sitatuation, prioritize targets and avoid all the different attacks. It's a classic!

HD is surprisingly faithful to the original. I kinda expected it to change a lot of core gameplay, but Croteam is just a honest indie company and gave a game just a nice graphics upgrade. Gameplay is almost same and the awesome soundtrack is completely identical. It's quite nice! And yep, even included Karnak from demo version, just like original. No technology test though.

And yea, it looks excellent, with much more natural looking desert and canyons. And if you take a careful look then you will see that some details that was just part of texture is now actual geometry, for example. Though, environment feels not fully finished, as inner places didn't get any additional details and some models seemed to have same textures quality, like statues, despite having more destruction phases. Just good nice new rendering with new light. Though I do wonder about some changes. For example, Alley of Spinxh levels is always at night and the third level of tomb has a fog changed from nice blue color to some dusty brown. As if Egypt doesn't have enough brown color with all sand.

But hey, look at all those great shiny weapons. And look at all the remade enemy models, now with ragdolls. Gore and weapons effects just got sexier, as you can now even gib part of enemies bodies, dismembering them, splitting apart, blowing head off with shotgun. It's awesome. Just look at the bull's death, where it would still slide around after being shot, leaving a trail of blood! And heavier enemies now can even be gibbed with a cannon, the heaviest weapon you have. The only strange thing is that Skeleton Kleers and Harpies are always gibbed upon death. For skeletons it looks good. But for harpies it looks strange, even gibs looks like just a few tiny chunks.

It also got some nice editing on gameplay. Some beheaded have a saw on their heads, giving them a melee attack. Bomberman looks fancy with that head on a spike, even. And heavy biomechanoids only shoot a single rocket when close to player, to let him have it easier, while it almost always was a certain death being very close to one in original. Kamikazes also seem to have smaller radius of explosion too. Flying gnaars seem to be more dangerous, not stopping when attacking. And weapons switch was made faster, which I approve. Though for some reason you can't walk anymore. Not that it ever was needed, just fancy.
If there is one thing I am most thankful the most is that new Netricsa messages notification is put somewhere to the side of a screen and doesn't grab your attention so you can ignore it easily. It was freaking annoying to be visually nagged by it everytime I killed each enemy types while playing custom maps in original.

Though, not everything is going perfect and some cuts had to be made. Most noticeably is that some of obscure engine features of Serious Engine 1 weren't implented in Serious Engine 3. Due to this, all the gravity-changing shenagians had to be cut. To be honest, I don't miss them too much, in Serious Sam 1 they were used only as funny thing in a bunch of a secrets, plus once non-secret usage in a secret level. It probably costed more time to reimplent them for something so small. I mean, at least when Croteam was making the first Serious Sam they had plans to make it much bigger game, with futurustic levels which would abuse gravity features. Once they cut it all to be Egypt-only, well, it was pretty much funky leftover.
It also doesn't have mirror and sliding surface, which I remember used only once.

They also seemed to screw up weapon balance slightly. You see, minigun was made to shoot two times slower, but each bullet does two times damage and is supposed to consume two ammo. But it only consumes one. Result: There is no more reason to use Thompson and you effectively have two times more ammo for minigun than in original. Oh well.
But hey, at least Laser gun isn't glitched in HD. It would sometimes start shooting only at half-speed in original. So flaw taken, flaw given.

And multiplayer is still awesome. Didn't get to cooperative, but I bet it's same spam, with same cutscene-skipping. And competetive part is awesome, still fast-paced. Although I noticed that rocket-jumping got nerfed and jumping off the slope doesn't give you additional height. But you are supposed to use knife to run fast and it still gets you in many places. And yep, still awesome arena-shooter which proves that you don't need some fancy strafejumping to be balanced and fast-paced.
Oh yea, and double shotgun in original was shooting at double speed. In HD it's same as in single-player/coop. Not sure what I think of it, but I think I like it this way. But maybe I need more experience with both ways.

Oh yea, and did you know that original The First Encounter was particulary embaressing due to having only a single DM level? Thankfully, HD added a bunch of them, even including Little Trouble from The Second Encounter. Hm, though HD multiplayer doesn't have scorematch mode, only fragmatch. But no one, absolutely no one, was playing scorematch in original anyway, so nah.

Overall, not perfect, but damn excellent HD remake with a bit of balance editing, untouched core gameplay, some environment upgrade and great gore system.
And yes, those who want to play Egypt levels in Serious Sam HD: The Second Encounter have to have this game purchased.

reviewText:
*jump**shoot**jump**shoot**jump**die**repeat*
6/10

+Fun system, pleasing to look for secrets and loot
+Updated graphics, but still has that old feel. If I didn't know it, I'd say my enemies were flat. (That's a good thing, trust me.)
+Runs 60 FPS on every system I've tested on, no matter what the graphics settings were
+Lots of customization in settings (Basically, you have the options to change what color/kind of blood you see, and how the atmosphere of the game looks like.)
+Database system encourages researching enemies, and quickly identifies the foe you are fighting

x Level design, it can be really good at times (Puzzles, mild parkour), but otherwise, it's straight and forward or it's an arena
x Lots of difficulty settings, but they feel really poorly designed (I'm playing at normal, and it seems way harder than normal. I've played easy, and it's way too easy. There's at least 6 different difficulty setings. :B)
x Saving! You can save, great right! Not really. So, in the game, you can press F6 to quickly save your game. Otherwise, if you die, you are set back to the start of the level. This sucks when you forget to save or are too busy getting blown up to save.
x Sound quality. First off, Sam is hilarious. He says some super-generic puns that'd you'd expect from a cheesy action movie or Duke Nukem. But, the enemies sounds... Well, you got the Kamikaze who screams his a** off when he charges, Scorpion bosses sound like someone taking a sh**, and the Bone Horse-thingies are too loud. The game's music isn't that great, but you can't really mute it, because sounds play such an important role in knowing when you're going to be attacked

-SUPER REPETITIVE, I kid you not. Combat doesn't change, it just gets harder because the enemies have more health, fire more bullets, or are more plenty in numbers. The combat is basically just jumping and shooting, avoiding enemy charges, or tearing down hoardes.
-LEVEL DESIGN! (I know I said this already, but...) There's this one level that was just agony. You start off with your pistols and shotgun (Only the shotgun does good damage) and you have to go into a large field with enemies. Once you kill them all, you have to fight another wave. Then, another wave of harder enemies come. Then , you fight a boss. Then, another boss, and then another, much larger boss. Again, this all takes place in the SAME FIELD.
-Plot doesn't justify the game. Why am I fighting? How did I get here? Why are these enemies spawning? Why are there so many? Why do they look the same? What am I looking for? Isn't there a much easier way? What do you mean I have to read about it? It'd be so much easier to explain if it took place in hell.

IN CONCLUSION[/b]
-Well worth the $1.50 I paid for both of the games
-A lot like old games like DOOM or the original Serious Sam
-You could probably get much more enjoyment from another game, but this game does have its perks
-I'd say it's NOT worth the Steam price (14.99 for the first game, 30.00 for both.)
-Good if you're looking for an easy-to-run game to pass the time

reviewText:
Synopsis:

The classic arcade FPS Serious Sam: The First Encounter, which scored an overall of 87% on Metacritic and was awarded Game of The Year 2001 on Gamespot, is now reborn in glorious high-definition for legions of long-time fans and a whole new generation of gamers around the world.

Featuring dazzling visuals and revamped design, gamers take control of the legendary Sam Serious Stone as he is sent back through time to ancient Egypt to battle the overwhelming forces of Notorious Mental and the Sirian army.
Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is essentially a remake of the original Serious Sam with a new Graphics Engine. New levels have been added and technically a new weapon, The Grenade Launcher, but this weapon was originally featured in Serious Sam: The Second Encounter.

The Graphics have been enhanced to a certain degree that someone new to the Serious Sam franchise will be able to jump right into it. Basically everything in game received the HD treatment, Weapon texturing and enemy texturing has vastly improved. Sound effects and music are pretty much still the same however.

Gameplay is pretty much identical to the original iteration so nothing much has changed. However this comes to the first part that REALLY gets on my nerves with this game. Enemy spawns are damn near AWFUL. I lost count of how many times I died due to a Kamikaze spawning literally right on top of me. Enemy placement sometimes getting downright frustrating at times with for example Kleer Skeletons basically camping doorways and you get double clawed" from two angles getting heavily damaged if not outright killed from such a attack. "Trap" Enemies are usually the work of lazy map designers. This same trap rule has been applied to ammo and health pickups as well adding on to the sentiment of being punished for picking up items which are supposed to help you.

While the game was enjoyable there are many aspects which make it feel cheap and lazy. My recommendation is to either stick with the Original games or get Serious Sam 3.

Final Score: 65/100"

Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is an old school shooter set in Acient Egypt, with the protagonist being Serious Sam, a superhuman badass who must go back in time to save Earth from Ugh Zan's invason of monsters! The game itself is amazing, with every minute being filled with non-stop action and shooting. Best part is, there are no objectives. 1 mission for every level: Make it to the end! Now i should note, if you want to start at the very beginning, play Serious Sam 3: BFE first, (BFE = Before first encounter).

The achievements in this game are insane, and serious dififculty almost made me ♥♥♥♥ing quit this game. Even on normal this game is tough as nails, but very fun and enjoyable. Another thing i love are the secrets. The secrets are so useful and cool, that even sometimes are surprising because of how much effort are put into 1 mesely secret. Now one of the BEST parts about this game are the enviorments. The grassy and sandy enviroments are so amazing, each level has its own unique enviorment, from sandy egypt-styled enviorments to grassy enviorments, the enivorments are one of my favorite parts about this game! Just look at these enviorments!

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=545805953

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=545805998

Especialy in the later levels, like Metropolis City. Hell, even the Sewer level didnt fail to give me a damn good level design!

There are 13 levels, (15 including the 2 secret levels), and each level is filled with monsters to gib and kill! There are also a lot of puzzles in this game too, mostly levers, pressure pads, etc, but these puzzles give the game a bit more to offer than just killing enemies. The 2 secret levels can be unlocked by doing certain things, but im not telling you how! :3

Now i must say, the game did give me some glitches, not game breaking glitches but otherwise minor glitches that were still noticable. I also thought that sometimes even on Normal that some parts seemed like i was playing on Serious, but then i remembered that this is an old school shooter, and that this is what an old school shooter is all about: Shooting and killing! Overall, Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is a blast to play! I highly reccommend it to anyone who loves a great old school shooter!

Welcome to the world of Serious Sam
date: a strange world where you goal is to kill anything that moves. Sound fun? It is! A ton of unique diverse levels for your crazy brain to plow through. Tons of enemies and great satisfying levels make for what should be a phenomenal game! Why isn't it then? Simply put the levels have some of the worst design choices I have ever seen in any game I have ever played. Sure some points the levels can be a blast
recommended: like the first half of City of Memphis - Metropolis where you have to go around a city styled maze and collect the 4 scarabs while avoiding the waves upon waves of different enemies that are searching for you in the maze
hoursPlayed: and City of Memphis - Sewers with some original designs and very generous enemy placements which make for a unique intense experience. However
voteText:
2 MAJOR flaws bring what should be a great game quickly down to some of my least favorite games of all time.

First MAJOR FLAW: Unfair Padding/ Poor Level Design:

Red signs of these problems start to appear however once you start playing the second half of the level City of Memphis - Metropolis
helpfulPercent: there is a pit with spikes with a chaingun that is supposed to spawn across from it to signify that you should go over there

votesFunny: a few dozen come flying at you and it shouldn't be a problem until those freaking skeleton running things come running at you and guess what... there are well over 100 of them. Earlier I did say how waves and waves can be fun... but only in well designed arenas like the one previously mentioned. However at this part it is just a straight hallway leading to a double door where they are spawning.They even continue to spawn even when you get on top of their spawn point making them practically impossible without rare or even unfair luck. Prior to this the level Oasis is entirely padding. From the first part of the level with the outside madness of hundreds to enemies to the "boss encounter". Why is it in quotes? Because
commentsCount: frogs... They decided that whenever creating a game
column16: if you want to pad a level over 8 minutes without putting in any effort is spawn hundreds of small enemies that kill you easily inside a small square room. GENIOUS! It's not that I am against difficult games
column17: because I am not (just look at my achievement list that includes Cave Story + Blood Stained Sanctuary which is one of the HARDEST levels in video game history). This happens more than once throughout each levels
column18: some more then others which makes the game very hard to enjoy. From what it seems
column19:
they took a lot of time designed the first part of a level (excluding everything in Oasis) and then just decided "Man I took way to long on that level and it's not even up to the adverage length! Lets spawn 1000000 enemies!" which is most unfortinute.

Second MAJOR FLAW: Enemy Spawning

As I stated above briefly whenever you get near where an enemy spawns it does regardless
column20: making for a practically instant death. An example is in Oasis in the first room you have the ability  to grab health on the edge of the valley. Once you get over there
column21:
enemies have the ability to spawn and can spawn directly on top of you which lead you directly to death. This happens a lot of the time in the game and really bogs down the experience.

Conclusion
And those are my main problems with the game. Does it make it terrible? No. Does it make it unenjoyable in every sense of the word? Yes. Unfortunately what Croteam fails to see is that when designing a level one should design it well and not but one hallway with a few hundred of the same enemies spammed to be sure to kill you artificially lengthening the level
column22: and expecting a player to know where an enemy spawns before it spawns which leads to an almost instant death is just cruel. I did finish the Demo Level on Hard difficulty and I had a blast. reviewText: Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is a very direct remake of the 2001 sleeper hit it is based on. To summarise, the game's an arcade focused FPS where you success is driven by fast reflexes and ability to chain points. Besides some glossy modern day improvements cosmetically including: a new physics engine, gore, some destructable environments and DX9c quality visuals, this edition is no different now as it was nearly ten years ago from release. It's fairly upsetting, and actually the game's flow still never manages to be as fluid or smooth as I remembered from all those years ago. Perhaps Serious Sam HD's biggest fault lies in that it hasn't taken advantage of any major gameplay improvements made in it's sequels, like Serious Sam: The Next Encounter on Gamecube even. The presentation is fairly average with below average menu navigation and poor multiplayer lobby support. It's an easy game to run, and supports the Xbox 360 controller but this release is tough to endorse otherwise.

Serious Sam, the character, is a time traveller sent back to ancient Egypt to fight aliens for reasons. Serious Sam, the game, feels more like it came from another dimension, a dimension where shooters never turns dust brown and clothed in ridiculous pretensions of militaristic realism. It is bright, colourful, imaginative and wilfully shallow and stupid.

To my mind the most pleasantly surprising thing about Serious Sam is how simultaneously thoughtful and mindless it is. The mindlessness is obvious, you shoot all the aliens with the big guns. The thoughtfulness springs from varied nature of the enemies and weapons combined with how refreshingly fair and open the designers were about their scripting.

The scripting is simple but brilliant. This is a game that will shamelessly spawn enemies directly in front of you if that is what the scripting calls for. This is game that doesn't give a damn about real world physical possibility so if it clashes with their level design then it can take a hike. On the other hand it also never appears to use infinite re-spawning of enemies. This allows for the player to play with the scripting, triggering a wave of enemies and then retreating slightly to deal with them before progressing. This might sound shoddy but it isn't, it really isn't, it is actually great because it allows the player to fully play the game rather than just experience it as a rollercoaster. This is a game that is made to be played rather than merely taken as some sort of an interactive cinematic experience. I won't spoil it but if you pay attention you'll notice the game even establishes an informal convention regarding some optional waves of enemies where the trigger can be identified and avoided by the play if they just want to continue.

Honestly, this isn't the sort of game I love. I was never a fan of old school shooters. I like to sneak about and take things slowly rather than charging in all guns blazing and all guns blazing is Serious Sam's thing. I can't deny that this sort of thing has its place though and this is perhaps the best game I've played of this type of shooter. If you've just had a stressful week and just need something loud and stupid to comfort you then Serious Sam might be just the thing.

Short Review:

Serious sam is a great, fast pace, FPS that is even better in HD

Long Review:

STORY: The game puts you in the shoes of, well, Serious Sam. Saving the Earth of Ailens trying to take it over. And that's all the story you need, Sam is every single badass from the 80's rolled into one. Though not as ego induced as Duke Nukem, he still just as awesome. Every single one-liner will make you laugh (even out loud).

GAMEPLAY: The gameplay of Serious Sam is like Duke Nukem 3D, see something, pump lead in it. But what makes Serious Sam differ from Duke Nukem is the enemies and how they work. In Serious Sam, enemies are more aggressive in nature and will come at you from every direction. While in Duke Nukem enemies stay in one place and wait for you to come. Serious Sam takes the FPS to the next level being tough as nails and it doesn't care if you're ready or not. It will throw everything at you.

LEVELS: Levels are large and open, giving you more room to run around and avoid thousands of enemies. The most you'll see in TFE is deserts and some jungle areas, even though the visuals don't change the layoout does, Making every level feel different from one another.

Overall I give Serious Sam a.... 9.8/10. Great levels, great gameplay, and a great main character. The only thing I would highly recommend is wait until the game's on sale. Because you can get TFE and TSE for only two dollars.

You have a set of weapons which consists of a knife, dual revolvers, a shotgun, a double barrelled shotgun, a Thompson, a mini-gun, a rocket launcher, a grenade launcher, a laser gun, and a cannon which is like a cannon of a ship but it fires cannon balls the size of boulders which will run over anything smaller than it and explode within contact of anything larger than it. There aren’t really any problems with serious sam but this game is very frustrating especially on the higher difficulties because this game is extremely difficult and it has some of the most annoying enemies in any game ever made and when you have a 100 of them bee lining towards you it’s just overwhelming. This is one of the best old school shooters ever made and you should definitely get this if you like old school shooters.

A 'cult classic' if there ever was one, if you like oldschool shooters you owe it to yourself to at least give this game a try.

Do yourself a favour and grab some friends, crank the enemy health up as high as it can go and have a blast getting your asses kicked, the crazy frantic action of the coop is what this game is most famous for but the singleplayer is still a wonderful challenge.
